If you find yourself in constant worry over anything and everything in your life, even when there should be no cause for concern, you might be suffering from Generalized Anxiety Disorder.

Generalized Anxiety Disorder is one of the most common anxiety disorders. While it can occur at any point of life, the most common points of onset occur between childhood and middle age. \nIf you are a woman, you are twice as likely to suffer from Generalized Anxiety Disorder than men.

Generalized Anxiety Disorder is different than having a phobia about something in the sense that people with GAD have an uneasy feeling about life in general. \nOften associated with feelings of dread or unease, you are in a state of constant worry over everything. There is no “off” switch. \nIf you are suffering from Generalized Anxiety Disorder, you are experiencing a constant state of worry – and you cannot avoid it, because life, in general, is causing you anxiety.

Studies have shown that if you are living with Generalized Anxiety Disorder, you are more likely to also suffer from other mental health issues and ailments. \nCommon conditions that are associated with Generalized Anxiety Disorder include depression(https://www.psycom.net/depression.central.html), irritable bowel syndrome, stress, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder(https://www.psycom.net/adult-adhd/), and substance abuse(https://www.psycom.net/depression.central.substance.html).
Some of the symptoms of GAD are:

• Perpetual state of constant worry
• Inability to relax or enjoy quiet time
• Muscle tightness or body aches
• Feeling tense
• Avoidance of stressful situations
• Difficulty concentrating or focusing on things
• No tolerance for uncertainty – needing to know what is going to happen and how it is going to happen
• Constant feelings of dread or apprehension
• Feeling overwhelmed and avoiding things or situations because of it
• Intrusive thoughts of things that cause you to worry – even when you try to stop thinking about them
• Feeling like you can’t control your emotions and constant worry – nothing you do helps you to relax
• Not being able to sleep at all or to sleep well because you are in a constant state of worry
• Feeling jumpy, on edge, or restless
• Stomach upset – including nausea and diarrhea
• Fatiguing easily
• Heart palpitations – feeling like your heart is racing
• Trembles or shakes
• Sweating and dry mouth
• Having difficulty breathing and/or feeling like you are choking
• Feeling lightheaded or dizzy
• Cold chills or hot flashes
• Numbness or tingling sensations
• Feeling like you have a lump in your throat
• Persistent irritability

This strategy focuses on feeling like you are \"back in control\" of yourself.
Make a list of all the things you need to do that you\'re utterly bogged down with.
Important: Be sure to include something really, really easy! Like \"make a cup of tea\", \"do the hair\" or simply \"take your controller back to the console\".
Make the cup of tea (or the one of the other easy things you have chosen).
While doing this, try to be aware and be in the moment. Think to yourself \"one thing is done!\". This might sound simple, but it is a huge step for your brain.
Pick something else from the list (another easy one).
When you get to a big one, you\'re already within a routine. It\'s all about getting back into control. \nBreak things down and keep crossing them off (don\'t miss this step!).
Credits to Dr. Wolfgang Hoi for the information.

Depression is more than just feeling sad. Everyone feels upset or unmotivated from time to time, but depression is more serious. \nIt is a mood disorder characterized by prolonged feelings of sadness and loss of interest in daily activities. If these symptoms persist for a period of at least two weeks, it is considered a depressive episode.
There is no one cause for depression, as it depends on a unique combination of an individual’s genetic makeup and environmental conditions. \nThere are many factors to take into account:

• The brain’s physical structure or chemistry
• History of depression in the family
• History of other disorders (anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder)
• Stressful, traumatic events (abuse, financial issues, death of a loved one)
• Hormone changes (menstrual cycles, pregnancy)
• Certain medications (sleeping aids, blood pressure medication)

We strongly suggest going through the following link for more information regarding the Types, Symptoms, Statistics and Treatment Options of Depression: https://www.psycom.net/depression.central.html\nDISCLAIMER: The creators of the app are not responsible for the information on the website.
Try to find 5 things that you can see and focus on that. \nThen focus on 5 things that you can feel and touch. \nFollow it up by 5 things that you can hear.

It\'s all about distracting your brain from the stressful heating. \nAt this moment, you may already be distracted enough that the worst part is over. \nIt’s simple, easy to remember and also easy to do.

If the distraction doesn\'t kick in, try to make this addition - focus on 5 things that you can smell. \nOr try to get your hands on a smell. It distracts you immediately and is a good way to get out of your state.
This game can also be expanded to thinking of animals, birds, colours, objects, movies, plants, foods, etc.
Credits to Dr. Wolfgang Hoi for the information.
This technique can be practiced anywhere, any time, even as long as you like. \nSo just try this when you out for a walk, being in your room, riding on a train, or even during an exercise.

• Take a minute or more (on purpose)
• Try being fully aware of what is going on in and around you
• Without any expectation or criticism (just a peaceful curiosity)
• Including the thoughts which come and go right now (sensations, feelings)

It\'s all about \"switching off the auto-pilot\", noticing and watching your thoughts and feelings and waking up to the physical sensations of things. \nTogether with deep-belly breathing, paying attention to your body and training the mind to observe, focus and filter. \nThis is a great thing to do while running. If you don\'t like it that way, try to make a chocolate-eating while being mindful. That is a whole new experience.

Try to browse through this list, if
• you’re facing a difficult problem or decision.
• you’re feeling overwhelmed by your options.
• you want to learn how to make better decisions.
8 steps to Problem Solving (credit to ReachOut)

1. Define the problem. What exactly is going on? Sometimes a problem just seems too big to tackle. However, if you make a list and break it down into smaller parts that you can make a start on solving, it’ll feel more manageable.

2. Set some goals. Focus on the steps you can take to resolve things, rather than just thinking about what you’d like to happen. Maybe you wish you had more money. Make a list of all the ways you can save or earn more. It could mean walking to school rather than taking the bus, or applying for a part-time job.

3. Brainstorm possible solutions. Be creative and come up with as many solutions as you can think of. Some ideas may be way out there, but don’t worry about evaluating them yet. If you want to solve a conflict you’re having with your parents by escaping on a rainbow unicorn, write it down! Keep an open mind and list anything that comes to mind, plausible or not.

4. Rule out any obvious poor options. Okay, reality check. Evaluate your list of ideas and rule out the ones that are unrealistic or unhelpful. Bye-bye, rainbow unicorn. But how about trying to see things from your parents’ point of view? That option should probably stay on your list.
5. Examine the consequences. Go through the options you’ve got left, and for each one write a list of their pros and cons.

6. Identify the best solutions. Now it’s time to make a decision. Look at your list of options, and pick out the ones that are most practical and helpful. There may be one obvious solution, or some might work in combination.
7. Put your solutions into practice. Have faith in yourself and make the commitment to try out one of your solutions.
8. How did it go? So, you tried it out. What happened? If you had more than one solution and the first didn’t work, move on to another one.

If nothing works out, try to grab some of your coping skills, from your personal toolbox. If your situation is still interfering with your day-to-day life, it’s a good idea to get some professional help. \nLooking for support is never a bad thing. If the first person is not the right one, look further!
Relaxing seems very easy, but is it really? \nA lot of people feel guilty for taking the time to relax or believe that they are \"wasting time\". Even worse, some think that they are being selfish.

Whether you are overwhelmed by work or personal things, taking time to relax is important. \nJust remember: you won’t have any resources (body or mind-wise) if you don\'t do it. \nIf you are too busy: just make the relaxation thing a routine, like an appointment with yourself!

Every single one of us has one. Our own unique collection of ways to deal with life, to get to a state of mental well-being. \nIt’s made up of things that only you have. Eg. What kind of personality you have, strengths and weaknesses, if you like being alone, or with people. Relaxing is a part of it. \nWith the right tools, everyone can flourish!

So think of it, what\'s in your toolbox? Are there some things missing, maybe others need a refill? Open for adjustments, additional aspects? \nMake a list or draw a toolbox, and put all the stuff in there, which is helping you.

Example: try to use voice memos! Just think of it like \"check in with yourself tool\" like \"how am i feeling right now, how am i doing?\" Use some nice wordings and listen to it every day. Your brain benefits from that.
Also, try to understand your stress. You probably already know what stresses you out. If not, it is easy to keep a \"stress diary\" at the end of every day.

In the diary, describe what happened and whether you felt stressed after. Is it a mental fuzziness, or a feeling of tightness in your tummy? Pay attention to such questions. Chronic worry, Pessimism or Perfectionism can be causes of stress.

Making lists is a very efficient way to relax or deal with stress, even if you are not \"a list person\" at all. Simply because the brain likes to bring things in order. So give it a try! \nThis can also be part of your well-being toolbox. \nSo, lets make a relaxation list, with things like:

• going for a walk
• having a bath
• reading
• meditating
• playing a video game
• chatting with friends
• etc...
You can refer to your relaxation list whenever you want to relax!
Credits to Dr. Wolfgang Hoi for the information

If you are in a crisis, you can help yourself by:

• Finding a therapist or a support group: Speaking to someone can make you feel better and improve your mental health.

• Building a support network: You don't have to deal with the crisis alone. People that you choose to confide in can help you. You can reach out via social networks, to your local community or to a close group of friends/family.

• Use your support network: Express yourself to people you trust. Keep an open mind to the advice that others give, understand that its coming from a good place. Show appreciation for the people who are helping you get through these tough times.

• Make a safety plan:

A safety plan is designed to guide you through a crisis. 
1. Recognize your personal warning signs: What thoughts, images, moods, situations, and behaviors indicate to you that a crisis may be developing? Write these down in your own words.
2. Use your own coping strategies: List things that you can do on your own to help you not act on urges to harm yourself.
3. Socialize with others who may offer support and distraction from the crisis: List people and social settings that may help take your mind off of difficult thoughts or feelings.
4. Contact family members or friends who may help to resolve a crisis: Make a list of people who are supportive and who you feel you can talk to when under stress.
5. Contact mental health professionals or agencies: Make a list of names, numbers and/or locations of clinicians, local emergency rooms, and crisis hotlines. 
6. Ensure your environment is safe: Have you thought of ways in which you might harm yourself? Work with a counselor to develop a plan to limit your access to these means.

How to identify if someone is at-risk:
They use phrases like \"I\'m feeling suicidal, I\'m scared\", \"I need to talk/need help\", \"I don\'t know how I can keep going\", \"I feel hopeless\"

If you have identified somebody that is at risk of suicide, you should to approach them carefully. Try not to act as a mental healthcare professional and get them in touch with appropriate resources such as a professional or a helpline.
If you think a person may be at imminent risk, call a suicide helpline or local emergency services.
